dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, the labor market's tightness has actually fallen to levels not seen since the Great Depression—what do you make of that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the labor market's tightness has actually fallen to levels not seen since the Great Depression-what do you make of that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tightness, an economic indicator that tracks the ratio of job vacancies to unemployment, has virtually returned to pre-pandemic levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's, uh, especially weird that voluntary turnover plummeted in September. Normally you'd expect people to jump ship when things improve, but they're stuck.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's, uh, especially weird that voluntary turnover plummeted in September. Normally you'd expect people to jump ship when things improve, but they're stuck.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Especially unusual is the rate at which employees are voluntarily quitting their jobs recovered in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Eliza Forsythe from Princeton says it looks like people who want to leave their jobs are absolutely stuck. That just flips the usual recession recovery script.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Eliza Forsythe from Princeton says it looks like people who want to leave their jobs are absolutely stuck. That just flips the usual recession recovery script.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We arent in the normal dynamic, says Eliza Forsythe, a professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who has studied the pandemic labor market. At this point, it doesnt look like people who want to leave their jobs are waiting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then you've got these companies like Microsoft and Salesforce eliminating remote work models, which feels like a huge misstep.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then you've got these companies like Microsoft and Salesforce eliminating remote work models, which feels like a huge misstep.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Microsoft and Salesforce, for example, are adopting permanent hybrid work models, while others like Dropbox, Twitter and Shopify will let their employees work from home indefinitely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. Paul McDonald at Goldman Sachs pointed out that inflexibility is key to turnover efforts. Like, forcing people back when they've adjusted to remote work?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. Paul McDonald at Goldman Sachs pointed out that inflexibility is key to turnover efforts. Like, forcing people back when they've adjusted to remote work?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The willingness to be flexible and accommodating to the changing needs of the workforce has been key to retention efforts, says Paul McDonald, senior executive director at the recruiting firm Robert Half.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the wage side—average hourly pay dropped from like, $30.80 to $28.17. That's gotta hurt retention even more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the wage side-average hourly pay dropped from like, thirty point eight zero dollars to twenty eight point one seven dollars. That's gotta hurt retention even more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After years of stagnation, average hourly wages for private sector employees grew from $28.80 in March 2020 to $30.17 in April 2021, according to data from the Federal Reserve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, Walmart paying zero cash bonuses to 1.5 million workers? Oof. Not exactly an incentive to stay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, Walmart paying zero cash bonuses to one point five million workers? Oof. Not exactly an incentive to stay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Walmart announced that it would pay its 1.5 million retail workers another $700 million in cash bonuses, contributing to a yearly total of $2.8 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got unemployment insurance and those pandemic bonuses—some say it's a massive driver for returning to work, others disagree.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got unemployment insurance and those pandemic bonuses-some say it's a massive driver for returning to work, others disagree.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unemployment insurance, with its elevated pandemic bonuses, has been offered as an explanation by policymakers and economists, though some analysts have pushed back, arguing that its effect on returning to work is minimal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's messy. And surveys about young people not leaving jobs? Forsythe says young folks always had low turnover rates anyway, even pre-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's messy. And surveys about young people not leaving jobs? Forsythe says young folks always had low turnover rates anyway, even pre-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In general, young people have pretty high turnover rates, says Forsythe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So maybe employers are overreacting by slashing flexibility instead of adapting. Childcare assistance, parental leave—those things matter now more than ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So maybe employers are overreacting by slashing flexibility instead of adapting. Childcare assistance, parental leave-those things matter now more than ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Childcare assistance, additional maternity or paternity leave, or subsidized tutoring can [also] be a huge differentiator for the employers offering them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. If the cost to replace someone is twice their salary, cutting perks and pay seems so short-sighted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. If the cost to replace someone is twice their salary, cutting perks and pay seems so short-sighted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the cost of replacing an employee can amount to twice their annual salary, a one-time bonus could be a critical long-term investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. This isn't a typical downturn—the rules have changed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. This isn't a typical downturn-the rules have changed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pandemic-driven recession hasnt been like most economic downturnsthe stock and housing markets have boomed, and after an initial shock last spring, retail sales have quickly rebounded.

artist_script:
HostA: So, the labor market's tightness has actually fallen to levels not seen since the Great Depression—what do you make of that?
HostB: Yeah, and it’s, uh, especially weird that voluntary turnover plummeted in September. Normally you’d expect people to jump ship when things improve, but they’re stuck.
HostA: Exactly. Eliza Forsythe from Princeton says it looks like people who want to leave their jobs are absolutely stuck. That just flips the usual recession recovery script.
HostB: Right? And then you’ve got these companies like Microsoft and Salesforce eliminating remote work models, which feels like a huge misstep.
HostA: Seriously. Paul McDonald at Goldman Sachs pointed out that inflexibility is key to turnover efforts. Like, forcing people back when they’ve adjusted to remote work?
HostB: And then there’s the wage side—average hourly pay dropped from like, $30.80 to $28.17. That’s gotta hurt retention even more.
HostA: Plus, Walmart paying zero cash bonuses to 1.5 million workers? Oof. Not exactly an incentive to stay.
HostB: But then you’ve got unemployment insurance and those pandemic bonuses—some say it’s a massive driver for returning to work, others disagree.
HostA: It’s messy. And surveys about young people not leaving jobs? Forsythe says young folks always had low turnover rates anyway, even pre-pandemic.
HostB: So maybe employers are overreacting by slashing flexibility instead of adapting. Childcare assistance, parental leave—those things matter now more than ever.
HostA: For sure. If the cost to replace someone is twice their salary, cutting perks and pay seems so short-sighted.
HostB: Absolutely. This isn’t a typical downturn—the rules have changed.
